title: Bibliographic guide to the foundations of quantum mechanics and quantum information
shortDesc: By Adan Cabello | A comprehensive collection of references on the foundations of quantum mechanics and quantum information science.
longDesc: This is a comprehensive collection of references (papers, books, preprints, book reviews, Ph. D. thesis, patents, web sites, etc.), sorted alphabetically and (some of them) classified by subject, on foundations of quantum mechanics and quantum information. Specifically, it covers hidden variables (“no-go” theorems, experiments), interpretations of quantum mechanics, entanglement, quantum effects (quantum Zeno effect, quantum erasure, “interaction-free” measurements, quantum “non-demolition” measurements), quantum information (cryptography, cloning, dense coding, teleportation), and quantum computation. The publication date is listed as 2004-11-15.
imageAlts: Front page of the Quantum Mechanics Bibliographic Guide
Abstract page of the Quantum Mechanics Bibliographic Guide
A page detailing references in the Quantum Mechanics Bibliographic Guide

title: Light cone dynamics and reverse Kibble-Zurek mechanism in two-dimensional superfluids following a quantum quench
shortDesc: By L. Mathey and A. Polkovnikov | A study on the light cone dynamics and the reverse Kibble-Zurek effect in 2D superfluids after a quantum quench.
longDesc: This academic paper investigates the dynamics of the relative phase of a bilayer of two-dimensional superfluids after decoupling. The research finds that on short time scales, the relative phase exhibits 'light cone' dynamics, creating a metastable superfluid state. This phenomenon, which suppresses vortex proliferation, is identified as a reverse-Kibble-Zurek effect. The study uses both numerical methods (truncated Wigner approximation) and an analytical time-dependent renormalization group approach (RG) to analyze the relaxation of the supercritical state to a disordered state via dynamical vortex unbinding. The RG approach suggests a non-equilibrium Kosterlitz-Thouless type phase transition.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Light Cone Dynamics
Abstract page of the physics paper
Figure or graph from the research paper

title: Observation of a 2D Bose-gas: from thermal to quasi-condensate to superfluid
shortDesc: By P. Cladé, C. Ryu, et al. | Experimental results on a Bose gas in a quasi-2D geometry near the Berezinskii, Kosterlitz and Thouless (BKT) transition temperature.
longDesc: This research paper presents experimental results on a **Bose gas** confined in a **quasi-2D geometry** near the **Berezinskii, Kosterlitz and Thouless (BKT) transition** temperature. The authors measured the density profile (both *in situ* and after time-of-flight) and the coherence length to identify different states of the gas. Key findings include the observation of a **bimodal distribution** without long-range order, a state where the gas is **quasi-condensed** but not yet superfluid, possessing a longer coherence length than the thermal cloud. The experimental evidence supports the observation of the actual superfluid transition (BKT transition).
imageAlts: First page of the paper on 2D Bose-gas observation
Abstract and introduction of the physics paper
Figure illustrating density profiles or coherence measurements

title: Ground-State Properties of a One-Dimensional System of Hard Rods
shortDesc: By F. Mazzanti, G. E. Astrakharchik, et al. | A quantum Monte Carlo simulation analyzing the ground-state phases of a 1D system of hard rods.
longDesc: This academic paper presents a **quantum Monte Carlo simulation** of a system composed of **hard rods in one dimension (1D)**. The calculation is exact due to the known analytical form of the wavefunction and aligns well with theoretical asymptotic expansions. Analysis of the **static structure factor** and the **pair distribution function** reveals the existence of two distinct phases: a **solid-like phase** at high densities and a **gas-like phase** at low densities. Crucially, the **one-body density matrix** decays via a power-law at large distances, which results in a divergence in the low-density momentum distribution at $k=0$, identifying the system as a **quasi-condensate**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on 1D Hard Rods system
Abstract and introduction of the physics paper
A figure illustrating the pair distribution function or momentum distribution

title: Observable dynamics and coordinate systems for vehicle tracking
shortDesc: By Richard Altendorfer | A study on various coordinate systems and dynamical vector fields for target tracking in driver assistance systems.
longDesc: This research investigates the use of different **coordinate systems** and **dynamical vector fields** for **target tracking** in the context of **driver assistance systems**. The paper demonstrates how to express the discrete dynamics of maneuvering target vehicles in arbitrary coordinates by starting from the dynamical models of both the target and the ego-vehicle in global coordinates. It clarifies the concept of **'ego compensation'** and outlines the necessary inclusion of **non-inertial effects** when employing a **body-fixed coordinate system** for tracking. The work concludes by comparing the tracking error produced by different coordinate and dynamical model combinations using simulated data.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on vehicle tracking dynamics
Abstract and introduction of the automotive engineering paper
A figure illustrating coordinate systems for vehicle tracking

title: Strain Effect on Energy Gaps of Armchair Graphene Nanoribbons
shortDesc: By Lian Sun, Qunxiang Li, et al. | A first-principles study on how uniaxial strain tunes the electronic energy gaps of Armchair Graphene Nanoribbons (AGNRs).
longDesc: This first-principles study investigates the electronic structures of deformed **armchair graphene nanoribbons (AGNRs)**. The research finds that the variation of the **energy gap** as a function of **uniaxial strain** displays a distinct **zigzag pattern**, indicating that the energy gaps of AGNRs can be effectively tuned. The paper also reports a swap in the spatial distributions of two occupied and two empty subbands close to the Fermi level under different strains. The tunable gap width is shown to narrow as the width of the AGNRs increases. Simulations using the **tight binding approximation** are shown to reproduce the first-principles results, and the study provides a simple empirical formula to describe the scaling behavior of the maximal energy gap with respect to AGNR width.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Graphene Nanoribbons
Abstract of the condensed matter physics paper
Figure illustrating the zigzag pattern of the energy gap vs. strain

title: Dynamical structure factor at small q for the XXZ spin-1/2 chain
shortDesc: By R. G. Pereira, J. Sirker, et al. | A study combining Bethe Ansatz and field theory to analyze the longitudinal dynamical structure factor for the anisotropic XXZ spin-1/2 chain.
longDesc: This theoretical physics paper investigates the **longitudinal dynamical structure factor S^zz(q, omega)** for the **anisotropic spin-1/2 chain** (the **XXZ chain**) within its gapless regime. The authors utilize a combination of **Bethe Ansatz** and **field theory (bosonization)** methods. They derive a low-energy effective model, which includes the leading irrelevant operators (band curvature terms) to account for boson decay processes. The coupling constants are determined exactly by comparing with Bethe Ansatz corrections to thermodynamic quantities. A key finding is that the width of the **on-shell peak** in **S^zz(q, omega)** scales like **delta omega_q ~ q^2**, a prediction that agrees with the two-particle continuum width calculated from the Bethe Ansatz equations. This scaling is only found to be violated near the isotropic point at finite magnetic fields. The results are compared against calculations using the **Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG)** for high accuracy.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on XXZ spin chain structure factor
Abstract of the theoretical physics journal article
A figure showing the dynamical structure factor S^zz(q, omega)

title: Quantum Monte Carlo with Directed Loops
shortDesc: By Olav F. Syljuasen and Anders W. Sandvik | Introduces the concept of directed loops to eliminate 'algorithmic discontinuities' in Quantum Monte Carlo methods.
longDesc: This paper introduces the concept of **directed loops** within **stochastic series expansion** and **path integral Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC)** methods. By establishing detailed balance rules for directed loops, the authors demonstrate a way to smoothly transition between generally applicable QMC schemes (which require back-tracking) and more restricted, specialized loop algorithms that avoid back-tracking. This technique successfully eliminates 'algorithmic discontinuities' across different regions in parameter space. As a key example, the paper applies directed loop simulations to the **anisotropic $S=1/2$ Heisenberg antiferromagnet** in an external magnetic field, showing high efficiency across the full range of fields and anisotropies, with significantly reduced autocorrelations. For the **2D Heisenberg model**, the method is used to study the magnetization process at low temperatures, yielding an accurate estimate of the **transverse susceptibility** in the thermodynamic limit: $\chi_{\perp} = 0.0659 \pm 0.0002$.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Quantum Monte Carlo with Directed Loops
Abstract of the computational physics journal article
A figure illustrating the magnetization curve or loop updates in QMC

title: The Energy-Scaling Approach to Phase-Ordering Growth Laws
shortDesc: By A. D. Rutenberg and A. J. Bray | A unified, self-consistent approach for determining the growth law $L(t)$ during phase-ordering kinetics using energy scaling.
longDesc: This paper presents a simple, unified method—the **Energy-Scaling Approach**—for determining the **growth law** for the characteristic length scale, $L(t)$, in the **phase ordering kinetics** of a system that is rapidly cooled (quenched) from a disordered state into an ordered phase. The approach determines $L(t)$ self-consistently for purely **dissipative dynamics** by calculating the time-dependence of the energy in two ways, based on a scaling assumption for pair correlations. The authors derive growth laws for both **conserved and non-conserved $O(n)$ models** (including 2D XY models) and systems with textures. The study concludes that the growth laws for complex systems like liquid crystals and Potts models are governed by the type of **topological defect** in the order parameter field that dominates the energy. Generalized **Porod laws** for systems exhibiting topological textures are also obtained.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Phase-Ordering Growth Laws
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
A figure illustrating growth laws in phase ordering kinetics

title: Will Zigzag Graphene Nanoribbon Turn to Half Metal under Electric Field?
shortDesc: By Er-Jun Kan, Zhenyu Li, et al. | Predicts the electric field-induced half-metallicity in zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNRs).
longDesc: This theoretical paper, conducted at the **B3LYP level of theory**, predicts that **half-metallicity** can be induced in a **zigzag edge graphene nanoribbon (ZGNR)** by applying an **external electric field** across the ribbon. Key findings show that the **critical electric field** required to realize half-metallicity decreases as the ribbon's width increases. The research also reveals that under very strong electric fields, the spin polarization and half-metallicity are removed when the edge state electrons fully transfer from one side to the other. Conversely, the useful electric field range for which the ZGNR remains half-metallic increases with the ribbon width. This rich field-induced **spin polarization** behavior suggests important applications in the field of **spintronics**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Zigzag Graphene Nanoribbon half-metallicity
Abstract of the computational materials science journal article
Figure illustrating the effect of electric field on the electronic band structure of ZGNR

title: Contractivity of positive and trace preserving maps under L_p norms
shortDesc: By David Perez-Garcia, Michael M. Wolf, et al. | A mathematical physics study on the contractivity of trace preserving positive maps with respect to p-norms.
longDesc: This academic paper provides a complete picture of **contractivity** of **trace preserving positive maps** with respect to **p-norms**. The authors show that for p > 1, contractivity generally holds if and only if the map is **unital**. When the domain is restricted to the traceless subspace of Hermitian matrices, contractivity is shown to hold for **qubits** for arbitrary $p \geq 1$ and for **qutrits** if and only if $p=1$ or $p=\infty$. In all cases where the map is non-contractive, the paper derives the best possible bounds on the p-norms.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Contractivity of maps under L_p norms
Abstract of the mathematical physics journal article
Figure or equation from the mathematical proof

title: Structure, Stability, Edge States and Aromaticity of Graphene Ribbons
shortDesc: By Tobias Wassmann, Ari P. Seitsonen, et al. | A DFT study on the stability, electronic structure, and magnetism of hydrogen-terminated graphene nanoribbon (GNR) edges.
longDesc: This paper uses **Density Functional Theory (DFT)** to investigate the stability, geometry, electronic, and magnetic structure of **hydrogen-terminated graphene-nanoribbon (GNR) edges** as a function of the hydrogen concentration in the environment. The authors find that **antiferromagnetic zigzag ribbons** are stable only at extremely low, ultra-vacuum pressures. Under more standard conditions, the most stable structures are **non-magnetic mono- and di-hydrogenated armchair edges** and a reconstructed zigzag edge. The paper shows that at high hydrogen concentrations, 'bulk' graphene is unstable and spontaneously forms ribbons, which explains experimental observations. The stability and the existence of exotic electronic states/magnetism are rationalized using simple concepts from **organic chemistry (Clar's rule)**, highlighting implications for future spintronic devices.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Graphene Ribbons stability
Abstract and introduction of the physics journal article discussing GNRs and spintronics
Figure or text detailing DFT calculations for GNR edge structures

title: A quantum computation architecture using optical tweezers
shortDesc: By Christof Weitenberg, Stefan Kuhr, et al. | Presents a complete and scalable quantum computation architecture using ultracold atoms in optical lattices manipulated by optical tweezers.
longDesc: This paper presents a complete architecture for **scalable quantum computation** using **ultracold atoms** trapped in **optical lattices** and manipulated by **optical tweezers** focused down to the size of a lattice spacing. It discusses three different **two-qubit gates** based on local collisional interactions. Implementing gates between arbitrary qubits requires the transport of atoms to neighboring sites. The authors numerically optimize the **non-adiabatic transport** of the atoms and the intensity ramps of the optical tweezer to maximize **gate fidelities**. They find overall gate times of a few 100 microseconds (us), with the error probability due to vibrational excitations and spontaneous scattering kept below 10^-3. The study concludes that atoms in optical lattices meet the necessary requirements for **fault-tolerant scalable quantum computing**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on quantum computation with optical tweezers
Abstract of the quantum physics journal article
Diagram illustrating the quantum computation architecture

title: Quantum transport theory of anomalous electric, thermoelectric, and thermal Hall effects in ferromagnets
shortDesc: By Shigeki Onoda, Naoyuki Sugimoto, and Naoto Nagaosa | A unified quantum transport theory for anomalous Hall effects (electric, thermoelectric, and thermal) in ferromagnetic metals.
longDesc:
This paper presents a **unified quantum transport theory** for the **anomalous Hall transport phenomena** (electric, thermoelectric, and thermal) in **ferromagnetic metals** with dilute impurities at zero temperature, using the **self-consistent T-matrix approximation**. The theory identifies three distinct regimes based on the scattering rate $\hbar/	au$ (where $E_F > E_{SO}$ are fixed): 

1.  **Superclean regime ($\hbar/	au < u_{imp} E_{SO}D$):** The **skew scattering** from the vertex correction dominates the anomalous Hall conductivity $\sigma_{xy}$, which rapidly decays as $\hbar/	au$ increases.
2.  **Moderately dirty regime ($u_{imp}E_{SO}D < \hbar/	au < E_{SO}$):** $\sigma_{xy}$ is dominated by the **intrinsic dissipationless Berry-phase contribution**, which is resonantly enhanced.
3.  **Very dirty regime:** A scaling relation $\sigma_{xy} \propto \sigma_{xx}^{1.6}$ appears, consistent with experimental verification. 

The study unifies the intrinsic (Berry-phase) and extrinsic (skew-scattering) origins of the anomalous Hall effect.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Quantum transport theory of Hall effects
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
A figure showing the three different transport regimes based on the scattering rate

title: Theory of a continuous Mott transition in two dimensions
shortDesc: By T. Senthil | Theoretical study of the zero-temperature continuous Mott transition in 2D systems, detailing the breakdown of the Fermi liquid state.
longDesc: This theoretical paper investigates the **zero-temperature phase transition** in two dimensions from a **Fermi liquid** to a **paramagnetic Mott insulator** featuring a spinon Fermi surface. The study shows that approaching the bandwidth-controlled **Mott transition** from the metallic side involves a vanishing **quasiparticle residue** and a diverging **effective mass**, along with diverging Landau parameters $F^0_s$ and $F^0_a$. The **quantum critical point** (QCP) possesses a 'critical Fermi surface' but no Landau quasiparticle, exhibiting a specific heat proportional to $T\ln(1/T)$ and a non-zero $T=0$ resistivity. The author predicts a remarkable **universal resistivity jump** in the residual resistivity at the QCP. Crossovers out of the critical region are also analyzed, notably an initial crossover to a **Marginal Fermi Liquid** metal before transitioning into the Landau Fermi liquid at lower temperatures. Implications for experiments on the layered triangular lattice organic material $\kappa-(ET)_2Cu_2(CN)_3$ are discussed.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on the continuous Mott transition theory
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure illustrating the phase diagram or critical region crossovers

title: Calculations of Maxwellian-averaged Cross Sections and Astrophysical Reaction Rates Using the ENDF/B-VII.0, JEFF-3.1, JENDL-3.3 and ENDF/B-VI.8 Evaluated Nuclear Reaction Data Libraries
shortDesc: By B. Pritychenko, S. F. Mughaghab, and A. A. Sonzogni | A comparative calculation of Maxwellian-averaged cross sections (MACS) and astrophysical reaction rates using four major nuclear data libraries.
longDesc: This paper focuses on calculating the **Maxwellian-averaged cross sections (MACS)** and **astrophysical reaction rates** for stellar nucleosynthesis reactions, including (n, $\gamma$), (n, fission), (n, p), (n, $\alpha$), and (n, 2n). The calculations were performed using four major evaluated nuclear-data libraries: **ENDF/B-VII.0**, **JEFF-3.1**, **JENDL-3.3**, and **ENDF/B-VI.8**. All libraries were processed under the same conditions for Maxwellian temperatures ($kT$) ranging from 1 keV to 1 MeV. The study compares the current calculations of the $s$-process nucleosynthesis nuclei with previous data sets and discusses the differences found, along with their implications for **nuclear astrophysics**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Maxwellian-averaged Cross Sections
Abstract of the nuclear astrophysics journal article
A table or figure comparing MACS values from different nuclear data libraries

title: Simple empirical algorithm to obtain signal envelope in three steps
shortDesc: By Cecilia Jarne | Proposes a simple, three-step empirical algorithm based on peak detection for obtaining the signal amplitude envelope.
longDesc: This paper proposes a simple, three-step **empirical algorithm** for obtaining the **signal amplitude envelope** based on **peak detection**. The envelope is noted as a slowly varying signal that should smoothly pass the prominent peaks of the data. This technique has been widely used in **sound analysis** and in the analysis of various physiological data for animal and human studies. The method was implemented using **Python libraries**. The study discusses the selection of parameters necessary to adapt the method for different applications in sound or general **time series analysis** and revisits some traditional envelope extraction methods.

title: Partitioning technique for a discrete quantum system
shortDesc: By L. Jin and Z. Song | Develops a partitioning technique to simplify the effective Hamiltonian calculation for quantum discrete systems represented as graphs.
longDesc: This paper develops a **partitioning technique** specifically for **quantum discrete systems**. The system is represented as a graph divided into a **central graph** and several **branch graphs**, where each branch is rooted by an individual node on the central graph. The main finding is that the **effective Hamiltonian** acting solely on the central graph can be accurately constructed by applying **additional potentials** to the branch-root nodes. This effective Hamiltonian yields the exact same physical results as the original Hamiltonian acting on the entire graph. The paper presents exactly solvable models to successfully demonstrate this technique.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on quantum discrete systems partitioning
Abstract of the quantum physics journal article
Diagram illustrating the central graph and branch graph partitioning technique

title: Tests of Lorentz invariance: a 2013 update
shortDesc: By Stefano Liberati | An updated 2013 review covering tests and constraints on Lorentz Invariance Violation (LIV) within Effective Field Theories (EFT) for matter and gravity.
longDesc: This paper presents an updated review of **Lorentz invariance tests** within **Effective Field Theories (EFT)**, covering both the matter and gravity sectors. Following a general discussion of Lorentz invariance and its derivation via the **von Ignatovski theorem**, the review details the dynamical frameworks developed in local EFT. It summarizes the available experimental and observational constraints on the parameters that govern **Lorentz Invariance Violation (LIV)** effects. The paper discusses two specific examples: the **OPERA 'affaire'** (a potential observation of superluminal neutrinos, serving as a case study and a caveat for applying LIV constraints), and the theoretical framework of **Ho\v{r}ava-Lifshitz gravity**, showing how these techniques apply to specific quantum gravity scenarios.
imageAlts: First page of the review paper on Tests of Lorentz Invariance
Abstract of the high energy physics journal article
A figure or section detailing constraints on Lorentz violating parameters

title: Damped Bogoliubov excitations of a condensate interacting with a static thermal cloud
shortDesc: By J. E. Williams and A. Griffin | Calculates the damping of condensate collective excitations at finite temperatures by modeling interactions with a static thermal cloud.
longDesc: This paper calculates the **damping** of **condensate collective excitations** at finite temperatures. This damping arises from the lack of equilibrium between the **Bose-Einstein condensate** and the surrounding **thermal atoms**. The authors simplify the problem by fixing the thermal cloud in static equilibrium, neglecting its dynamics. They derive a set of **generalized Bogoliubov equations** for finite temperatures which explicitly include a damping term due to the **collisional exchange of atoms** between the two components. By numerically solving these equations, they obtain the temperature dependence of the damping of the condensate modes in a **harmonic trap** and compare the results to their previous work using the Thomas-Fermi approximation.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Damped Bogoliubov excitations
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure illustrating the damping rate versus temperature in a harmonic trap

title: Capillary Waves in a Colloid-Polymer Interface
shortDesc: By R. L. C. Vink, J. Horbach, and K. Binder | Analysis of the structure and statistical fluctuations of colloid-polymer interfaces using Monte Carlo simulations of the Asakura-Oosawa (AO) model.
longDesc: This paper analyzes the structure and **statistical fluctuations of interfaces** between coexisting phases in the **Asakura-Oosawa (AO) model** for a **colloid-polymer mixture**. The analysis is performed using extensive **Monte Carlo simulations** with a grand canonical cluster move technique. By simulating very large systems, the researchers analyze the spectrum of **capillary wave-type interfacial excitations**. The study confirms **capillary wave theory** for small wavevectors but observes pronounced deviations for larger ones. For wavevectors corresponding to the typical distance between colloids, interfacial fluctuations show the same structure as the bulk structure factor. Analysis of the data reveals a monotonous decrease of the **wavevector-dependent interfacial tension** with increasing wavevector.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Capillary Waves in a Colloid-Polymer Interface
Abstract and introduction of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure or graph illustrating capillary wave spectrum or interfacial tension versus wavevector

title: Landau damping: instability mechanism of superfluid Bose gases moving in optical lattices
shortDesc: By Kiyohito Iigaya, Satoru Konabe, et al. | Investigates Landau damping as the microscopic mechanism for the instability of superfluid Bose gases moving in optical lattices at finite temperatures.
longDesc: This paper investigates **Landau damping** of **Bogoliubov excitations** in a dilute **Bose gas** moving within an **optical lattice** at finite temperatures. Using a 1D tight-binding model, the authors explicitly calculate the Landau damping rate. They find that the sign of the damping rate, which determines the **condensate stability**, changes at a specific condensate velocity. This velocity is **exactly the same** as the **critical velocity** determined by the **Landau criterion of superfluidity**. This coincidence reveals the **microscopic mechanism** of the Landau instability. This instability is consistent with experimental observations suggesting the **thermal cloud** plays a crucial role in the breakdown of superfluids, as the thermal cloud is also vital for the Landau damping process. The paper also examines conditions for the simultaneous disappearance of all damping processes.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Landau damping and superfluid instability
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure illustrating the Landau damping rate as a function of condensate velocity

title: On the exact electric and magnetic fields of an electric dipole
shortDesc: By W. J. M. Kort-Kamp and C. Farina | Derives the exact expressions for the electric and magnetic fields of an arbitrarily time-dependent electric dipole using a multipole expansion from Jefimenko's equations.
longDesc: This paper derives the **exact expressions** for the **electric (E) and magnetic (B) fields** generated by an **electric dipole** with an **arbitrary time dependence**. The derivation uses a **multipole expansion** derived directly from **Jefimenko's equations** (the time-dependent generalizations of Coulomb's and Biot-Savart's laws). The authors also include comments on the usual, and often incomplete, expositions of these fields found in common undergraduate and graduate textbooks on electromagnetism.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on electric dipole fields
Abstract of the electromagnetism journal article
Equations detailing the multipole expansion for time-dependent fields

title: Spinodal decomposition in fluids: diffusive, viscous and inertial regimes
shortDesc: By Turab Lookman, Yanan Wu, et al. | Examines domain growth during spinodal decomposition in fluids across diffusive, viscous, and inertial regimes using a Langevin description.
longDesc: This study uses a **Langevin description** to examine **domain growth** during **spinodal decomposition** in fluids. The research covers three distinct dynamic regimes: **diffusive**, **viscous**, and **inertial**. Within the framework of this model, numerical results are presented that **corroborate earlier theoretical predictions** based on scaling arguments and dimensional analysis. Spinodal decomposition is a phase separation mechanism where a single phase separates into two phases within the unstable region of the phase diagram.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Spinodal decomposition in fluids
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure showing domain growth patterns in the diffusive, viscous, and inertial regimes

title: Second-order QCD corrections to the thrust distribution
shortDesc: By A. Gehrmann-De Ridder, T. Gehrmann, et al. | Computes the next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO) QCD corrections to the thrust distribution in electron-positron annihilation.
longDesc: This paper presents the computation of the **next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO)** corrections from **Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD)** to the **thrust distribution** in **electron-positron (e+e-) annihilation**. The computed corrections are found to be sizable, enhancing the previously known **Next-to-Leading Order (NLO)** prediction by approximately **15%**. The inclusion of these NNLO corrections is shown to **significantly reduce the theoretical renormalisation scale uncertainty** associated with the prediction of the thrust distribution, thereby improving the precision of theoretical predictions in high-energy physics.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on QCD corrections to thrust distribution
Abstract of the high-energy physics journal article
Graph comparing NLO and NNLO predictions for the thrust distribution

title: Coexistence in locally regulated competing populations and survival of branching annihilating random walk
shortDesc: By Jochen Blath, Alison Etheridge, and Mark Meredith | Introduces two lattice-based models for competing populations, proving coexistence and the survival of branching annihilating random walk (BARW).
longDesc: This paper proposes two **lattice-based models** describing the evolution of a pair of **competing populations**. The models serve as a compromise between fully spatial models (which are hard to analyze) and standard interacting particle systems. The second model simplifies competition to act only within lattice sites, maintaining a constant total population size per site. A special case of this second model is shown to be **dual to a branching annihilating random walk (BARW)**. Using a comparison technique based on **oriented percolation**, the authors demonstrate that for certain parameter ranges, both populations will **coexist** for all time with a positive probability. A direct result (corollary) is the **survival for all time of BARW** when the branching rates are sufficiently large. The paper concludes by presenting conjectures concerning the role of space in the survival probabilities of the two populations.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Competing Populations and Random Walk
Abstract of the probability theory and mathematical physics journal article
Diagram or equations illustrating the lattice-based population model or oriented percolation comparison

title: Spin-flop transition in uniaxial antiferromagnets: magnetic phases, reorientation effects, multidomain states
shortDesc: By A. N. Bogdanov, A. V. Zhuravlev, and U. K. Roessler | A comprehensive phenomenological theory of the spin-flop transition in easy-axis antiferromagnets, including multidomain states.
longDesc: This paper develops a comprehensive **phenomenological theory** for the **spin-flop transition** in **easy-axis antiferromagnets**. The spin-flop is a field-driven **first-order reorientation transition** where the sub-lattice magnetizations 'flop' away from the easy axis. The theory shows that the hierarchy of magnetic coupling strengths results in a strong **two-scale character** in the magnetic phase structure. Near the spin-flop region, the antiferromagnets can be described by an effective model similar to uniaxial ferromagnets, provided that **higher-order anisotropy** and **dipolar stray-fields** are included. Crucially, the authors show that **thermodynamically stable multidomain states** exist in the spin-flop region due to the **phase coexistence** at this first-order transition. The paper derives the equilibrium spin-configurations and parameters for these multidomain states. Anomalies in the calculated **magnetic susceptibility tensor** components are proposed as an efficient method to investigate magnetic states and determine material parameters in bulk, confined, and nanoscale synthetic antiferromagnets. This method is demonstrated using experimental data for the layered antiferromagnet **(C_2H_5NH_3)_2CuCl_4**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Spin-flop transition in antiferromagnets
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Figure illustrating the magnetic phase diagram or multidomain states near the spin-flop transition

title: Field and current distributions and ac losses in a bifilar stack of superconducting strips
shortDesc: By John R. Clem | Analytical calculation of magnetic field, current distribution, and AC losses in a bifilar stack of thin superconducting strips using critical-state theory.
longDesc: This paper analytically calculates the **magnetic-field** and **sheet-current distributions** generated in an **infinite bifilar stack** of thin **superconducting strips**. The strips are characterized by opposite net currents and analyzed under the assumption of **critical-state theory**. The strips have thickness $d$, width $2a >> d$, and arbitrary separation $D$. The author derives expressions for the **AC losses** due to magnetic-flux penetration from both the strip edges and the top/bottom surfaces. The results are expressed in terms of integrals involving the perpendicular and parallel components of the magnetic field. After numerical evaluation for typical dimensions, the paper provides simplified **analytic expressions** that can be used to estimate these losses, which is critical for the design of superconducting devices.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on superconducting strip losses
Abstract of the applied superconductivity journal article
Diagram or graph showing current and magnetic field distributions in the bifilar strip stack

title: Constructive Quantum Shannon Decomposition from Cartan Involutions
shortDesc: By Byron Drury and Peter J. Love | Extends the Quantum Shannon Decomposition using Cartan decompositions to provide a simple, constructive algorithm for unitary matrix synthesis.
longDesc: This work extends the well-known universal quantum circuit, the **Quantum Shannon Decomposition (QSD)**. The authors identify the basis of the QSD circuit design in a pair of **Cartan decompositions**. This theoretical insight leads to the development of a simple **constructive algorithm** for obtaining the Quantum Shannon Decomposition of any given **unitary matrix** in terms of the corresponding **Cartan involutions**. This result is significant for the field of **quantum computing** as it provides a practical method for synthesizing quantum logic circuits.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Quantum Shannon Decomposition
Abstract of the quantum information journal article
Diagram or equations related to the Cartan decomposition and unitary synthesis

title: Tunability of the k-space Location of the Dirac Cones in the Topological Crystalline Insulator Pb1-xSnxTe
shortDesc: By Y. Tanaka, T. Sato, et al. | Studies the evolution and tunability of Dirac cones in the topological crystalline insulator (TCI) Pb1-xSnxTe using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES).
longDesc: This study performs systematic **angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES)** on the **Topological Crystalline Insulator (TCI)** compound **Pb1-xSnxTe** to map the evolution of its electronic states across the **topological phase transition**. The research confirms that SnTe (x = 1.0) exhibits a pair of **Dirac-cone surface states** located symmetrically across the Xbar point. As the compound approaches the trivial phase (at $x_c$ approximately 0.25), the Dirac cones are shown to **gradually move toward the Xbar point** while their spectral weight decreases. For samples with $x \le 0.2$, the Dirac-cone surface state vanishes completely, confirming the phase transition. The evolution of the valence band is consistent with the **bulk band inversion** occurring at $x_c$. The **tunability of the k-space location** of the Dirac cones is highlighted as a useful feature for future applications like **spin injection**, which require Fermi-surface matching with other materials.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Dirac cones in topological crystalline insulators
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
ARPES band mapping images showing the tunability of the Dirac cone position with changing tin concentration (x)

title: Quantum Monte Carlo simulation of a two-dimensional Bose gas
shortDesc: By S. Pilati, J. Boronat, et al. | Calculates the equation of state and properties of a homogeneous 2D Bose gas using Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) methods.
longDesc: This paper calculates the **equation of state** of a **homogeneous two-dimensional (2D) Bose gas** using **Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) methods**. The authors investigate the universal behavior at low densities using various interatomic model potentials, including both finite-ranged and strictly repulsive potentials, as well as a zero-ranged pseudopotential supporting a bound state. They calculate the **condensate fraction** and the **pair distribution function** across a wide range of the gas parameter, covering the **dilute** to the **strongly correlated regime**. For the zero-range pseudopotential, they specifically analyze the **stability of the gas-like state** for large scattering lengths and calculate the **critical density** at which the system becomes unstable and begins forming clusters.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on 2D Bose gas QMC simulation
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article
Graph showing the equation of state or condensate fraction as a function of the gas parameter

title: The Gross-Pitaevskii Equation for Bose Particles in a Double Well Potential: Two Mode Models and Beyond
shortDesc: By R. G. Scott, R. F. O'Connell, et al. (Full author list not provided in the abstract) | Investigates the dynamics of Bose particles in a double-well potential using the Gross-Pitaevskii equation and comparing it to simpler two-mode models.
longDesc: This paper investigates the dynamics of **Bose particles** confined in a **double-well potential** by analyzing the **Gross-Pitaevskii (GP) equation**. The study compares the full GP equation results with those obtained from simplified **two-mode models**. The double-well potential is a fundamental system for studying quantum phase transitions, coherence, and tunneling in **Bose-Einstein Condensates (BECs)**. By analyzing the GP equation in this configuration, the work explores phenomena beyond the limitations of the traditional two-mode approximation, providing deeper insight into the behavior of the BEC when tunneling between the two wells.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on the Gross-Pitaevskii Equation in a Double Well Potential
Introduction of the condensed matter physics journal article

title: Thin superconductors and SQUIDs in perpendicular magnetic field
shortDesc: By Ernst Helmut Brandt | Method for calculating static and dynamic electromagnetic properties, current distribution, and magnetic field in thin superconducting films and SQUIDs exposed to a perpendicular magnetic field.
longDesc: This paper presents a general method for calculating the **static and dynamic electromagnetic properties** of **thin flat superconducting films** of arbitrary shape and size, including multiply connected geometries used for **SQUIDs (Superconducting Quantum Interference Devices)**. The calculation accounts for any value of the effective **London penetration depth (Lambda)** and an applied **perpendicular magnetic field**. As examples, the distributions of **sheet current** and **magnetic field** are derived for rectangular and circular films (with and without slits/holes), in response to the applied field and to **magnetic vortices** moving within the film. The paper details the **self-energy** and **interaction** of these vortices, noting that, due to the long-ranging magnetic stray field, these energies depend strongly on the size and shape of the film, unlike in large bulk superconductors. It also compares the **focussing of magnetic flux** into the central hole of square films with and without a radial slit.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on thin superconductors and SQUIDs
Abstract of the condensed matter physics journal article

title: Scalar density fluctuation at critical end point in NJL model
shortDesc: By H. Fujii | Investigates the nature of the soft mode near the critical end point in the phase diagram of the two-flavor Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model.
longDesc: This paper investigates the **soft mode** located near the **critical end point (CEP)** in the phase diagram of the two-flavor **Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model**. The analysis is performed within the leading $1/N_c$ approximation, where $N_c$ is the number of colors. By studying the **spectral function** of the **scalar channel**, the author explicitly demonstrates that the relevant soft mode is the **scalar density fluctuation**, which is coupled with the **quark number density**. In contrast, the **sigma meson mode** is found to remain massive. This identification of the scalar density fluctuation as the soft mode provides crucial information for understanding the physics of the CEP in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) effective models.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on scalar density fluctuation in NJL model
Abstract of the high energy physics journal article
Graph showing the spectral function and the location of the critical end point

title: Dark Matter Detectors as Dark Photon Helioscopes
shortDesc: By Haipeng An, Maxim Pospelov, and Josef Pradler | Proposes using low-threshold Dark Matter experiments (like XENON10) as sensitive helioscopes to search for light 'dark' vector bosons (dark photons) emitted by the Sun.
longDesc: This paper investigates the possibility of detecting **light new particles** (masses below 10 keV), which are expected to be emitted from the solar interior and are plausible extensions to the Standard Model. Specifically, the authors analyze a new **'dark' vector state $V$** (a massive vector boson, or **dark photon**) that mixes with the photon via an angle $\kappa$. For small mass $m_V$, the dark photon's emission spectrum is strongly peaked at low energies. The study utilizes constraints on the atomic ionization rate from the **XENON10 experiment** (a low-threshold **Dark Matter detector**) to set the limit on the model parameters: $\kappa \cdot m_V < 3 \times 10^{-12}$ eV. This demonstrates that low-threshold Dark Matter experiments function as the **most sensitive dark vector helioscopes**. This result improves current experimental bounds from other searches by several orders of magnitude and surpasses stringent astrophysical and cosmological limits across a wide mass interval of $m_V$. The approach is generalized to set the most stringent direct constraints on **'mini-charged' particles**.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on Dark Matter Detectors as Dark Photon Helioscopes
Abstract of the high energy physics and astrophysics journal article
A figure showing the constraints on the dark photon mixing parameter $\kappa$ versus mass $m_V$

title: Dynamical surface gravity
shortDesc: By Alex B. Nielsen and Jong Hyuk Yoon | Discusses and compares various definitions of surface gravity for dynamical black holes, focusing on locally defined horizons.
longDesc: This paper discusses how **surface gravity** can be **classically defined** for **dynamical black holes**. The focus is on defining surface gravity for **locally defined horizons**, and the authors compare several definitions that have been proposed in the literature. They illustrate the differences between these various proposals using the case of an **arbitrary dynamical, spherically symmetric black hole spacetime**. The paper also discusses the relationship between the **trapping horizon formalism** developed by Hayward and other existing constructions for defining gravitational properties of non-static black holes.
imageAlts: First page of the paper on dynamical surface gravity
Abstract of the general relativity and quantum cosmology journal article
